### **Booklet Printing & Binding (A5 saddle‑fold)**

**1. Adjust page settings**  
- In your word processor or PDF app, choose **A5** (148 × 210 mm / 5.8 × 8.3 in).  
- Set all margins to 0.5 in (13 mm).  
- In *Print → Layout → Booklet* (available in most printers or Acrobat Reader), select “2 pages per side” / “Flip on short edge.”  
This will place pages 1 + 4 on one sheet and 2 + 3 on the reverse.

**2. Paper choice**  
Use slightly heavier stock (100–120 gsm). It resists show‑through and folds crisply without cracking.

**3. Printing**  
- Print a single test sheet first to check orientation; the title and back text should face opposite sides of the same sheet.  
- Once correct, print the remaining sets.  
- Let ink dry for a few minutes before handling.

**4. Folding**  
Align the sheets precisely and fold in half along the short edge; run the back of a spoon or a bone folder along the crease for a neat bind.

**5. Binding options**  
- Two small staples at the fold (saddle stitch), **or**  
- Thread a simple string through two punched holes, tie inside.  
Keep binding light so pages open flat for writing.

**6. Label & store**  
Add the workbook title on the spine with a fine‑tip pen. Keep a few blank copies ready if you use these for recurring practice.

**7. Safety note**  
Ensure the self‑care information — calling or texting **988** in the U.S. or a local number elsewhere — prints clearly on the last page before folding. It’s meant to be visible when the booklet is closed.

   *Title*, *Author*, *Subject*, *Keywords*, *Version*, *Edition Date*.  
   Fill your current values (you can update “Version” each time you revise).  
4. Click OK → Save.

**2 · link those properties to your document**
Anywhere you want the version or date to appear automatically —
(for example, on the footer beside your “created by” line):

*In Windows Word*  
- **Insert → Quick Parts → Field → Document Information → DocProperty → (select the field)**  
- Example: insert `DocProperty Edition Date` in your footer; Word will now display whatever you recorded in the custom properties.

**3 · export to PDF**
When you choose **File → Export → Create PDF/XPS**, Word includes those properties in the PDF’s metadata block automatically, matching the fields you filled.

*Verification:* open the PDF in Acrobat → File → Properties → “Description.” You should see your data under Title, Author, etc.

**4 · update for each new edition**
Simply return to **File → Info → Properties → Advanced Properties**, change *Version* or *Edition Date*, and re‑export.  
All linked fields and metadata will refresh without manual edits on every page.

You can do that neatly and without affecting the rest of your margin setup by putting the glyph into the page header rather than the body text.  

Here’s how to set it up:

---

### **Embedding a Constant Glyph or Logo in Word**

**1 · Prepare the graphic**
* If you’re using the ⟡ or ∿ character as a logo, you can simply insert it as text.
* If you prefer a small image—SVG or transparent PNG at about 1 cm wide—save it once and name it something like `QuietGlyph.svg`.

**2 · Place it in the header**
1. Double‑click the top margin area to open the **Header & Footer Tools** ribbon.  
2. **Insert → Text → Quick Parts → Field → DocProperty → Edition Date** *(optional if you also want the edition number up there).*  
3. Next to that, **Insert → Picture → This Device** and choose your glyph image – or type ⟡ / ∿ directly.  
4. With the image/character selected, set **Layout Options → Behind Text** so it won’t move your text margins.  
5. Align it using the ruler or **Position → Horizontal: Center, Vertical: 0.5 cm from Top margin.**

**3 · Lock the placement**
Check **Different First Page** if you want the glyph larger on the cover and smaller on remaining pages.  
Uncheck *Link to Previous* if you need slightly altered size or tint on the back cover.

**4 · Color and consistency**
Match its hue to your accent line (`#9DB7C0` muted blue or `#A9B1B3` gray).  
Use **Format → Color → More Colors → Custom → RGB** to enter exact values.

**5 · Export**
When you save as PDF, Word retains header graphics and vector glyphs automatically.  
Open the exported file once to be sure the symbol sits cleanly above the main content and margins aren’t shifted.

---

**Tip:** Keep a copy of the glyph in a small vector file so you can reuse it across future edition templates; consistent headers quietly signal that each version belongs to the same *Quiet Performance* series.
